The original NEAT C++ is from about 2002, so you are right it has not 
been=
 updated in a long time.

However, the rtNEAT C++ (http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/=
keyword?rtneat) 
actally contains an updated regular NEAT implementation (t=
hat is, it 
can be used without the "rt" part).  It was also stripped of al=
l the 
extra libraries like gtkmm and guile to make it easier to compile on=
 
its own, or with your own libraries.

Therefore, I recommend using rtNEAT=
 in NEAT mode instead of the 
original NEAT.

In addition, there are a lot =
of options for NEAT implementations for 
various platforms and languages, i=
ncluding C# and Jave.  Many are 
linked from the software section of my hom=
epage:

http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software


ken

in
